coredata.dc:title: 2D sp2 carbon-conjugated triazine covalent organic framework photocatalysis for blue light-induced selective oxidation of sulfides with O2
coredata.dc:creator: Hao, Huimin
Zhang, Fulin
Dong, Xiaoyun
Lang, Xianjun
coredata.dc:description: Triazine, possessing planar and fully conjugated attributes, purveys ample space to construct well-defined crystalline polymers like graphic carbon nitrides (g-C3N4), covalent triazine frameworks (CTFs), and covalent organic frameworks (COFs). Herein, g-C3N4, CTF-1, and TP-COF were successfully synthesized and systematically confirmed by a series of characterizations, aiming at visible light photocatalytic activation of O2. Compared to CTF-1 and g-C3N4, TP-COF was endowed with the best photocatalytic performance by several inherent properties, including a large specific surface area, a suitable bandgap, and superior charge transfer. The blue light-induced selective conversion of organic sulfides has been achieved expeditiously with O2 over TP-COF photocatalyst. Moreover, rigorous control experiments and in situ electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) suggest that electron and energy transfer pathways contribute to the selective formation of desired sulfoxides. This work emphasizes that the tailor-made trait of COFs provides an ideal plarform of customizing two-dimensional (2D) photoactive COFs based on triazine for visible light-induced selective chemical transformations.
coredata.dcterms:subject: 2D covalent organic frameworks
sp2 carbon-conjugation
Triazine
Blue light
Selective oxidation

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: The PXRD patterns of (a) g-C3N4; (b) CTF-1; (c) TP-COF.
The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of (a) g-C3N4; (b) CTF-1; (c) TP-COF at 77 K.
(a) UV–Vis DRS of g-C3N4, CTF-1, and TP-COF; (b) Tauc plots obtained with Kubelka–Munk function and the linear fit for optical bandgaps of g-C3N4, CTF-1, and TP-COF.
(a–c) Mott–Schottky plots of g-C3N4, CTF-1, and TP-COF, respectively; (d) the calculated positions of LUMO and HOMO of g-C3N4, CTF-1, and TP-COF.
(a) Blue light-induced photocurrents of g-C3N4, CTF-1, and TP-COF; (b) Nyquist plots from EIS of g-C3N4, CTF-1, and TP-COF.

Comparison of g-C3N4, CTF-1, and TP-COF on the blue light-induced selective oxidation of three organic sulfides with O2. Reaction conditions: sulfide (0.5 mmol), photocatalyst (5 mg), CH3OH (1 mL), blue LEDs (3 W × 4), O2 (0.1 MPa), 15 min. The conversions of sulfides were determined by GC–FID using bromobenzene as the internal standard.

(a) The influence of different LEDs on the visible light-induced selective oxidation of phenyl methyl sulfide with O2 over TP-COF; (b) The recycling tests of TP-COF on the blue light-induced selective oxidation of phenyl methyl sulfide with O2. Reaction conditions: phenyl methyl sulfide (0.5 mmol), TP-COF (5 mg), CH3OH (1 mL), LEDs (3 W × 4), O2 (0.1 MPa), reaction time (a) 0.6 h, (b) 0.5 h. The yields of phenyl methyl sulfoxide were determined by GC–FID using bromobenzene as the internal standard.
(a) SEM image; (b) AFM image (Inset: thickness distribution of the dotted line); (c) TEM image; (d) SAED of TP-COF.
Kinetic study on the blue light-induced selective oxidation of phenyl methyl sulfide with O2 over TP-COF photocatalyst in CH3OH and CD3OD.

The EPR signal recording of (a) electrons; (b) spin trapping of O2 •- with DMPO; (c) spin trapping of 1O2 with TMPD in the blue light-induced selective oxidation of sulfides over TP-COF photocatalyst.
The proposed reaction pathways for the blue light-induced selective oxidation of phenyl methyl sulfide with O2 over TP-COF photocatalyst.
Quenching experiments to determine the ROS for the blue light-induced selective oxidation of phenyl methyl sulfide with O2 over TP-COF. a

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: The blue light-induced selective oxidation of organic sulfides with O2 over TP-COF photocatalyst

head.ce:title: 2D sp2 carbon-conjugated triazine covalent organic framework photocatalysis for blue light-induced selective oxidation of sulfides with O2

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Sauvage Center for Molecular Sciences, College of Chemistry and Molecular Sciences, Wuhan University, Wuhan 430072, China

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: Sauvage Center for Molecular Sciences, College of Chemistry and Molecular Sciences, Wuhan University

ce:affiliation.ce:source-text: Sauvage Center for Molecular Sciences, College of Chemistry and Molecular Sciences, Wuhan University, Wuhan 430072, China

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Triazine, possessing planar and fully conjugated attributes, purveys ample space to construct well-defined crystalline polymers like graphic carbon nitrides (g-C3N4), covalent triazine frameworks (CTFs), and covalent organic frameworks (COFs). Herein, g-C3N4, CTF-1, and TP-COF were successfully synthesized and systematically confirmed by a series of characterizations, aiming at visible light photocatalytic activation of O2. Compared to CTF-1 and g-C3N4, TP-COF was endowed with the best photocatalytic performance by several inherent properties, including a large specific surface area, a suitable bandgap, and superior charge transfer. The blue light-induced selective conversion of organic sulfides has been achieved expeditiously with O2 over TP-COF photocatalyst. Moreover, rigorous control experiments and in situ electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) suggest that electron and energy transfer pathways contribute to the selective formation of desired sulfoxides. This work emphasizes that the tailor-made trait of COFs provides an ideal plarform of customizing two-dimensional (2D) photoactive COFs based on triazine for visible light-induced selective chemical transformations.

ce:section.ce:para: Since the seminal report of visible light-induced production of H2 over g-C3N4, the potential of conjugated polymer photocatalysts featured with diverse and adjustable structure has been realized substantially to approach the challenges in energy and environment [1–4]. As prospective alternatives of traditional inorganic semiconductors, conjugated polymers have exhibited high propensity in converting and utilizing solar energy [5–7]. It is worth mentioning that conjugated polymer photocatalysts can be tailor-made at the molecular level. Generally, good crystallinity has a reasonably positive effect on the photo-induced charge transfer like inorganic semiconductors. Therefore, vigorous development is undergoing on crystalline conjugated polymer photocatalysts.

As one of the most well-known photocatalysts, g-C3N4 holds many merits like being metal free, high chemical stability, abundance in raw material, and straightforward preparation [8,9]. After unremitting efforts, g-C3N4 had been extensively engaged in a myriad of photocatalytic reactions such as the production of H2 [10], degradation of pollutants [11], and evolution of O2 [12]. However, g-C3N4 suffers from the fast charge-carrier recombination and limited visible light utilization [13]. Many effective strategies such as constructing heterojunction, defects regulation, element doping [14–19] have been implemented to settle these problems. However, the differentiation of g-C3N4 structure is complex, and the diversity of g-C3N4 is quite limited. Fortunately, these prior endeavors on g-C3N4 lay a firm foundation for strategically designing new photocatalysts with superior activity. For example, many g-C3N4 photocatalysts were built straightforwardly from the triazine-containing molecule melamine under high temperature treatment. Thus, one can start with the triazine core unit to chemically synthesize well-defined photocatalysts under mild conditions.

Endowed with diverse structures based on triazine core units, CTFs have broken the limitation of g-C3N4 to some extent [20,21]. Nowadays, CTFs have become versatile photocatalysts to pollutant degradation, water splitting, organic transformations, and CO2 reduction [22–25]. As visible light photocatalysts, the traits of CTFs involve a wide range of monomers and robust chemical stability. However, the restriction of crystallinity lingers on CTFs [26]. In general, CTFs were synthesized by the cyclotrimerization reaction of cyano groups, aromatic amides, and so on [27–30]. Considering the weak reversibility of cyclotrimerization, the preparation of high crystalline CTFs remains a challenge [31].

Besides, both g-C3N4 and CTFs could not sufficiently activate O2 even though they are powerful photocatalysts for other reactions. This is attributed to their ill-suited position of lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) endowed by their building blocks. Thus, new linkages should be conceived without amending the desirable triazine core unit. Some more versatile synthetic routes to obtain the highly crystalline triazine COFs prevail [32–35]. Principally, the synthesis of COFs desires the reversibility of linkages and precise control over reaction conditions, which are favorable to the dynamic self-repairing of defects [36]. Introducing highly reversible dynamic chemical bonds as the linkage to construct COFs can improve crystallinity. Varying from boronate ester [37], azines [38], imines [39] to hydrazine [40], olefin [41,42], the linkages of COFs have achieved continuous development. Distinctly, the sp2 carbon-conjugated linkage in COFs stands out as one of the best-anticipated categories, benefiting from the superior chemical stability, extended electron delocalization, and excellent photocatalytic performance [43,44]. Hitherto, sp2 carbon-conjugated COFs have been designed for cathode material of lithium-ion batteries [45], reduction of CO2 [46], oxidation of benzylamines [47], production of H2 [48], and regeneration of coenzyme [49,50], etc. Thereby, inheriting the core units of g-C3N4 and CTFs, the potential of sp2 carbon-conjugated triazine COFs is expected to be exploited in visible light photocatalytic activation of O2.

Herein, three triazine-cored crystalline conjugated polymers g-C3N4, CTF-1, and TP-COF were synthesized. Wherein g-C3N4 and CTF-1 were synthesized according to the previous methods [15,31]. TP-COF conjugated by sp2 carbon was synthesized via Knoevenagel condensation reaction (Scheme S1). It is worth noting that the –CC– linkage in sp2 carbon-conjugated COFs is generally difficult to construct, and therefore precise control of the reaction conditions is necessary [43]. Further, g-C3N4, CTF-1, and TP-COF were employed to activate O2 for the blue light-induced selective oxidation of organic sulfides. Due to several inherent properties, including a large specific surface area, a suitable bandgap, and superior charge transfer, TP-COF acted as the most competent photocatalyst for blue light-induced selective oxidation of organic sulfides with O2. This work emphasizes the tailor-made trait of sp2 carbon-conjugated 2D COFs in visible light photocatalysis, which offers a paradigm for maneuvering photoactive COFs.

ce:section.ce:section-title: The synthesis of TP-COF, CTF-1, and g-C3N4
ce:section.ce:para: Considering the solvent's polarity, boiling point, the solubility and other factors, o-dichlorobenzene was chosen as the solvent after several attempts. As a moderate base, cesium carbonate (Cs2CO3) is helpful to capacitate the reversibility in the formation of –CC– bond, then it was selected as the catalyst to synthesize TP-COF. Finally, an available solvothermal method was summarized, by which high crystallinity TP-COF was prepared. In detail, 2,4,6-tris(4-formylphenyl)-1,3,5-triazine (TFPT, 0.048 mmol, 18.88 mg), p-phenylenediacetonitrile (PDAN, 0.072 mmol, 11.25 mg), Cs2CO3 (0.288 mmol, 93.84 mg), and o-dichlorobenzene (2 mL) were added into a 10 mL Pyrex tube. After being ultrasonicated for 3 min, the mixture was degassed by freeze–pump–thaw cycles three times and sealed with flame. The mixture was heated at 150 ℃ for 72 h. Cooling to room temperature, the precipitate was washed by water and tetrahydrofuran (THF) several times, extracted by Soxhlet with THF and ethanol for 72 h, dried at 120 ℃ under vacuum for 12 h. Finally, a yellow powder was produced. The required TFPT was synthesized in three steps (Scheme S2, Supplementary data). CTF-1 and g-C3N4 were synthesized successfully according to previous reports [15,31]. More experimental details are in Supplementary data.

ce:section.ce:section-title: The typical procedure for the photocatalytic oxidation of sulfides
ce:section.ce:para: At the start, add 0.5 mmol of sulfide and 5 mg of TP-COF into a 10 mL Pyrex reactor containing 1 mL of CH3OH as the solvent. The mixture was stirred for half an hour to achieve adsorption-desorption equilibrium under the dark condition. Next, the Pyrex reactor was sealed and filled with O2 to 0.1 MPa. Afterward, blue light-induced oxidation of sulfide in the Pyrex reactor was submitted to magnetic stirring of 1500 rpm. In the end, the photocatalyst were separated from the reaction mixture by centrifugation. And the reaction products were analyzed by gas chromatography equipped with a flame ionization detector (GC–FID) using bromobenzene as the internal standard. The products were confirmed by comparison with the retention time with authentic samples by GC–FID (Agilent 7890B) and further affirmed by gas chromatography–mass spectrometry (GC–MS, Agilent 5977B GC/MSD).

ce:section.ce:section-title: ynthesis and characterization of g-C3N4, CTF-1, and TP-COF
ce:section.ce:para: The g-C3N4, CTF-1, and TP-COF were synthesized and subsequently characterized by various technical means. In the Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra of TP-COF, PDAN, and TFPT (Fig. S1), the peak at 1705 cm−1 is assigned to stretching vibration of –CO; and the peaks at 2216 cm−1 and 2249 cm−1 are attributed to the stretching vibration of –CN. Compared to PDAN and TFPT, TP-COF displays the consumption of aldehyde groups and the retention of cyano groups obviously, revealing the formation of TP-COF. According to the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of g-C3N4 ( Fig. 1a), the intense peak of 2θ at 27.5° is specific for the (002) crystal plane, caused by the interlayer stacking of the conjugated aromatic structure; while the weak peak at 13.2° is assigned to the (100) diffraction plane, from the in-plane repeat arrangement of tri-s-triazine. These observations demonstrate the successful formation of g-C3N4 from melamine. About CTF-1 (Fig. 1b), the peak at 7.1° corresponds to the (100) in-plane reflection, the peaks at 12.4°, 14.4°, 18.8° are ascribed to the (110), (200), and (210) plane reflections and the peak of 26.2° is attributed to the interlayer stacking layers (002). From the PXRD pattern of TP-COF (Fig. 1c), the characteristic sharp peak at 2.8° is assigned to the (100) crystal plane, which is a powerful evidence that the prepared TP-COF owns high crystallinity; the peaks at 4.8°, 5.6°, 7.4° are ascribed to the (110), (200), and (210) planes, respectively. Hence, all three triazine-cored crystalline polymers of g-C3N4, CTF-1, and TP-COF were synthesized successfully.

To assess the porosity of g-C3N4, CTF-1, and TP-COF, the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of these samples were recorded at 77 K ( Fig. 2). The N2 sorption isotherms of g-C3N4 and CTF-1 are close to type III isotherms (Fig. 2a and b). However, the sorption isotherm of TP-COF displays a noticeable uptake at the low relative pressure and a hysteresis loop, which suggests the existence of micropores and mesopores in the structure (Fig. 2c). The specific surface area of TP-COF was calculated as 680 m2 g−1 using Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method. Moreover, the pore size distribution of TP-COF was obtained based on the N2-DFT model. The two peaks at 1.3 nm and 2.5 nm (Fig. S2) are approximately close to the pore size values of the eclipsed AA stacking structure [49].

The UV–visible diffuse reflectance spectra (UV–Vis DRS) of g-C3N4, CTF-1, and TP-COF are depicted in Fig. 3a. Wherein g-C3N4 has the absorption edge at the wavelength of 450 nm. The absorption edges of CTF-1 and TP-COF extend to 600 nm, exhibiting their broad visible-light harvesting. With Tauc plots obtained from Kubelka–Munk function, the optical bandgaps of g-C3N4, CTF-1, and TP-COF are estimated to be 2.85 eV, 2.26 eV, and 2.39 eV, respectively (Fig. 3b).

Next, the semiconducting behaviors of g-C3N4, CTF-1, and TP-COF were further investigated. First, Mott–Schottky plots of g-C3N4, CTF-1, and TP-COF were acquired ( Fig. 4a-c). The positive slopes of plots reveal that g-C3N4, CTF-1, and TP-COF are n-type semiconductors. Theoretically, the flat-band potential (Efb) of g-C3N4, CTF-1, and TP-COF could be linearly fitted to be − 0.80 V, − 0.77 V, − 0.71 V vs. Ag/AgCl from the intercept of the x-axis. Considering that the bottom of the LUMO position of an n-type semiconductor is approximately equal to its flat-band potential, the relative position of LUMO for g-C3N4, CTF-1, and TP-COF were acquired as − 0.80 V, − 0.77 V, and − 0.71 V vs. Ag/AgCl, which are more negative than the potential of O2/O2 •- (− 0.48 V vs. Ag/AgCl). Combining with the values of bandgap from the Tauc plots, the position of highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) can be gained as well (Fig. 4d). Thus, it could be concluded that g-C3N4, CTF-1, and TP-COF are capable for the activation of O2 in which TP-COF position most suitably.

The photoelectric properties of g-C3N4, CTF-1, and TP-COF were analyzed by more electrochemical techniques ( Fig. 5). Compared to g-C3N4 and CTF-1, the much stronger photocurrent response of TP-COF implies the better separation and mobility for photo-induced charge carriers (Fig. 5a). The arc radius of TP-COF on Nyquist plot from electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) is smaller than those of g-C3N4 and CTF-1, affirming the higher charge transfer efficiency. Likewise the smaller interfacial impedance of TP-COF (Fig. 5b), implies that TP-COF could be the most efficient photocatalyst.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Photocatalytic selective oxidation of sulfides with O2
ce:section.ce:para: Subsequently, g-C3N4, CTF-1, and TP-COF were utilized for the blue light-induced selective oxidation of organic sulfides. Specifically, phenyl methyl sulfide and two 4-substituted phenyl methyl sulfides were used as the reactants ( Fig. 6). As a result, the selective oxidation of the three sulfides over CTF-1 and g-C3N4 evolved sluggishly, while TP-COF delivered superior photocatalytic performance. As for the reason, the best photocatalytic activity of TP-COF benefits from the larger specific surface area, better separation and mobility capability of photo-induced charges, smaller interfacial resistance, which has been verified by the photocurrent response and EIS.

Under the irradiation of different peak wavelength (λp) LEDs, the selective oxidation of phenyl methyl sulfide demonstrates differentiated yields of phenyl methyl sulfoxide over TP-COF photocatalyst ( Fig. 7a). Taking account of the remarkable conversion, blue LEDs were appointed as the standard light source in the following experiments, whose light-emitting spectrum is presented in Fig. S3. As a control experiment, the oxidation of sulfide at 40 ℃ under dark condition was conducted, and the reaction did not occur. Moreover, with the increase of light intensity, the conversions for the oxidation of phenyl methyl sulfide continue to increase (Table S1). Therefore, it is a genuine light-induced reaction rather than a thermal-induced reaction. Additionally, the robustness of TP-COF photocatalyst was affirmed by the results of recycling experiments (Fig. 7b). After four runs, the yields of phenyl methyl sulfoxide were maintained at a high level, which directly proves the stability of the photocatalyst. In the fifth run, the yield of phenyl methyl sulfoxide had some slight drop, which might be ascribed to the inadequate recovery of TP-COF photocatalyst. This is inevitable after operations of repeated recycling.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Morphology of TP-COF photocatalyst and mechanistic investigations
ce:section.ce:para: As a photocatalyst with excellent performance, it is essential to observe the morphology of TP-COF. Judging from the scanning electron microscope (SEM) image and atomic force microscope (AFM) image ( Fig. 8a and b), TP-COF presents a 2D layered structure with a uniform thickness of approximately 0.8 nm. In the transmission electron microscope (TEM) image (Fig. 8c), the distinct interlayer fringes can be observed, and the interlayer spacing is measured as 0.34 nm. From the selected area electron diffraction (SAED) of TP-COF (Fig. 8d), the crystal plane indices of these concentric diffraction rings respectively correspond to (100), (110), (200) from the inside to the outside, revealing that TP-COF is a polycrystalline material with the simple hexagonal structure. Besides, the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curve depicts that TP-COF has good thermal stability, less than 20% weight loss at 600 ℃ (Fig. S4). Thus, TP-COF photocatalyst is robust enough to undertake aerobic oxidation reactions.

After tracking the reaction process, it was discovered that this reaction conforms to the zero-order reaction ( Fig. 9). Explicitly, the concentration of phenyl methyl sulfide does not control the reaction rate. Furthermore, reaction rate constants k in CH3OH and CD3OD were calculated as 0.01422 mol L−1 min−1 and 0.01924 mol L−1 min−1, respectively. Because CD3OD is an 1O2 maintainer, the larger reaction rate constant illustrates that 1O2 contributes to the oxidation of phenyl methyl sulfide as one form of reactive oxygen species (ROS). However, the inconsiderable difference in reaction rate constants suggests that energy transfer pathway to 1O2 only plays a minor role in converting phenyl methyl sulfide.

During selective oxidation, determining the ROS plays a key role in understanding the reaction mechanism, controlling the distribution of product, designing novel reaction system and so on. Quenching experiments were conducted to determine the ROS for the blue light-induced selective aerobic oxidation of phenyl methyl sulfide over TP-COF photocatalyst ( Table 1). In the standard reaction conditions, the oxidation can reach the conversion of 85% with O2 as the oxidant (Table 1, Entry 1). Conversely, using atmospheric O2 as the oxidant, the phenyl methyl sulfide can be oxidized with a conversion of 33%. When N2 filled the system to replace O2, the reaction did not occur (Table 1, Entry 2). Hereafter, when p-benzoquinone (p-BQ) and 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane (DABCO) were respectively added to the standard reaction as O2 •- scavenger and 1O2 scavenger, the conversion of phenyl methyl sulfide declined to different degrees (Table 1, Entries 3 and 4), declaring both O2 •- and 1O2 existed in the photocatalytic system. With the addition of electron scavenger AgNO3, the oxidation of phenyl methyl sulfide dropped markedly, which was ascribed to the blocked electron transfer to O2 (Table 1, Entry 5). In summary, it was proved that both electron and energy transfer pathways contribute to the formation of desired sulfoxides in this reaction. Besides, the notable difference in conversion after adding p-BQ advocates electron transfer pathway to O2 •- plays a major role in converting phenyl methyl sulfide.

EPR is a powerful technique to examine free radicals. In this photocatalytic system, the signals of electrons from excited TP-COF, O2 •-, and 1O2 were recorded in Fig. 10. The blue light-induced accumulation of electrons of LUMO were detected over TP-COF photocatalyst (Fig. 10a). The signals of electrons became stronger and stronger as the irradiation time increased, suggesting the growth of photo-generated electrons. Once O2 was poured into the system, the signal of electron weakened, implying the consuption of electrons by O2. The signals of O2 •- captured by 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline N-oxide (DMPO) displayed the evolution of O2 •- evidently with the course of irradiation time (Fig. 10b). Further, 1O2 was investigated by utilizing 2,2,6,6-tetramethyl-4-piperidone (TMPD) as a spin-trapping probe. And the signals enhanced gradually with the progress of time (Fig. 10c). Thence, both electron transfer and energy transfer exist over TP-COF photocatalyst, consistent with the results of ROS quenching experiments.

The electron transfer processes of inorganic materials have been well established in photocatalysis and electrocatalysis [51–54], offering a window to elucidate the blue light-induced electron transfer pathway over TP-COF photocatalyst. Consequently, the rational reaction pathways of the blue light-induced selective oxidation of phenyl methyl sulfide with O2 over TP-COF photocatalyst are proposed ( Fig. 11). The blue light-induced electrons of TP-COF migrate from HOMO to LUMO, generating the separated electron-hole pairs. In the electron transfer pathway, hole extracts an electron from phenyl methyl sulfide. And the S-central free radical cation intermediate is produced. Correspondingly, the electron combines with O2, producing the O2 •- as the ROS. Further, O2 •- attacks the phenyl methyl sulfide radical cation to furnish phenyl methyl persulfoxide. With the assistance of protons from the solvent CH3OH, the final phenyl methyl sulfoxide is obtained. In the energy transfer pathway, the recombination of excitons yields the other ROS 1O2 over TP-COF, which directly convert phenyl methyl sulfide into phenyl methyl persulfoxide. In like manner, the solvent CH3OH facilitates the generation of phenyl methyl sulfoxide in the end.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Scope of organic sulfides over TP-COF photocatalyst
ce:section.ce:para: Sulfoxides are vital pharmaceutical intermediates, and visible light-induced selective oxidation of sulfides is an important route to obtain sulfoxides, featuring mild reaction conditions, atom economy, and environmental friendliness [55–57]. Therefore, it is imperative to extend the substrate scope by TP-COF photocatalysis ( Table 2). Compared to other heterogeneous photocatalysts (Table S2), the performance of TP-COF is outstanding for the selective oxidation of phenyl methyl sulfide. The oxidation of majority of para-substituted phenyl methyl sulfides could be achieved with excellent conversion and selectivity. Electron-donating group substituted phenyl methyl sulfides (Table 2, Entries 1–3) were easier to complete the oxidation than phenyl methyl sulfides (Table 2, Entry 4), while electron-withdrawing group substituted phenyl methyl sulfides were slightly slower (Table 2, Entries 5–7). Furthermore, the participation of the –NO2 group led to a low conversion after an equal time due to the extremely strong electron-withdrawing effect (Table 2, Entry 8). To investigate the influence of the position of the substituted groups, the selective oxidation of the ortho- and meta-chlorophenyl methyl sulfides were conducted over TP-COF photocatalyst (Table 2, Entries 9 and 10). Compared to para-chlorophenyl methyl sulfide, it took a longer time for ortho- and meta-chlorophenyl methyl sulfides to reach a comparable conversion, owing to the steric hindrance effect. In addition, the blue light-induced oxidation of phenyl ethyl sulfide attained the conversion of 83% and selectivity of 97% for 0.6 h (Table 2, Entry 11). As for diphenyl sulfide, enhanced steric hindrance retarded the photocatalytic reaction severely (Table 2, Entry 12) because the substituted phenyl group is too bulky. In contrast, the photocatalytic selective oxidation of aliphatic sulfides proceeded smoothly with no difficulty (Table 2, Entries 13 and 14). Overall, TP-COF performed preeminent photocatalytic activity and possessed convincing universality for the selective oxidation of a series of organic sulfides with O2 under environmentally benign conditions.

With triazine as the core unit, g-C3N4, CTF-1, and TP-COF were prepared successfully. After comprehensive characterizations, they were adopted for the blue light-induced selective oxidation of organic sulfides with O2 as the exclusive oxidant. The large specific surface area, extended conjugated framework, robust stability, and superior charge transfer endow TP-COF with the best photocatalytic performance, revealing the untapped potential of sp2 carbon-conjugated triazine COFs in visible light photocatalysis. More intriguingly, both electron transfer and energy transfer exist during the blue light-induced selective oxidation of sulfides to sulfoxides with O2 over TP-COF photocatalyst. This work emphasizes the tailor-made trait of sp2 carbon-conjugated COFs, which provides an ideal platform of customizing 2D photoactive COFs based on triazine for photocatalytic selective chemical transformations.

Huimin Hao: Investigation, Writing – original draft. Fulin Zhang: Investigation, Formal analysis. Xiaoyun Dong: Investigation, Formal analysis. Xianjun Lang: Conceptualization, Supervision, Writing – review & editing, Funding acquisition.

ce:conflict-of-interest.ce:para: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.

ce:acknowledgment.ce:para: This work was financially supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (grant numbers 22072108 and 21773173).
